editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

div.head: To all Lovers & Practitioners OF M∆≤SICK.
div.p:
I Was de≈øired by ≈øome Ma≈øters to Print the Scale of Mu≈øick, or Gam-ut, in a halfe ≈øheet of Paper, to put in a Schollers Book, to ≈øave the pains of writing; which I intended onely to have done; but upon ≈øecond thoughts I have altred my minde, and made the addition of ≈øome nece≈ø≈øary plain Rules for the better under≈øtanding thereof, and the help of Beginners. I confe≈øs, men better able then my ≈øelfe might have ≈øpared my pains, but their ≈ølowne≈ø≈øe and mode≈øty (being as I conceive unwilling to appear in Print about
≈øo ≈ømall a matter) hath put me upon the Worke, which I count very u≈øefull, though with the danger of not being ≈øo well done, as they might have performed it. The Rules of all Arts ought to bee delivered in plaine and briefe language, and not with flowers of Eloquence; and ≈øo this Worke is more ≈øutable to my abilities.

The Work as it is I mu≈øt confe≈ø≈øe is not all my owne, ≈øome part of it was collected out of other mens writings, which I hope will the more commend it: and if the brevity, plainne≈ø≈øe, and u≈øefulne≈ø≈øe thereof may beget acceptance with thee, it will encourage me to do thee more ≈øervice in other things of this nature.

div.head: CHAP. I. Of the Scale of MUSICK, called the Gam-ut.
div.p: THe GAM-UT is the Ground and Foundation of Mu≈øick both Vocall and In≈øtrumentall, and as Ornithop ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ chus reporteth, it was compo≈øed by Guido Aretinus about the yeare 960. who al≈øo in ≈øix ≈øyllables, which hee found in the fir≈øt Saphick of the Hymne of S. Johannis Baptista.

It is ≈øuppo≈øed he drew the ≈øix names of the Notes, viz. UT, RE, MI, FA, SOL, LA, which were ≈øo generally taught and practi≈øed in the ≈øame order, a≈øcending, and de≈øcending: but in the≈øe latter times foure of them are onely in u≈øe, which are SOL, LA, MI, FA; ≈øo that UT and RE are changed into SOL LA, and the≈øe foure being found to be ≈øufficient for
the expre≈ø≈øing of the ≈øeverall ≈øounds, and le≈ø≈øe burthen≈øome to the memory.

Be≈øides the≈øe names of the Notes there is u≈øed in the GAM-UT ≈øeven Letters of the Alphabet, which are ≈øet at the beginning of each Rule and Space, as G. A. B. C. D. E. F. and of the≈øe there are three Septenaries a≈øcending one above the other, G. being put fir≈øt, which is according to the third Letter in the Greeke Alphabet called Gamma, and is made thus r, in token that the fir≈øt derivation thereof was from the ancient Greeks.

The≈øe ≈øeven Letters of the Alphabet are called the 7 Cliffs, or more properly Cleaves, the other names or ≈øylables adjoyned to them, the Notes: And by the≈øe three Septenaries are di≈øtingui≈øhed the ≈øeverall tones or ≈øounds, which the Scale is divided into: Fir≈øt the Ba≈ø≈øe, which is the lowe≈øt part; the ≈øecond the Meane, or middle part; the third, the Treble, or highe≈øt part, ≈øo that according to the≈øe three Septenaries, Gam-ut is the lowe≈øt Note, and Ela the highe≈øt: And this the u≈øuall Gam-uts in Mr. Morley and others, do not exceed; but it is well known that there are many Notes in u≈øe, both above and below exceed that compa≈øs, both in Vocall and In≈øtrumentall Mu≈øick, and therefore ought not to bee omitted; for the Compa≈øs of Mu≈øick ought not to be confin'd: for though there be but three Septenaries in the Gam ut of the Alphabet, which expre≈ø≈øe the ≈øeverall ≈øounds, yet if occa≈øion requires, you may a≈øcend one more higher, for it is but the ≈øame again,
onely eight Notes higher; or if occa≈øion require, you may de≈øcend lower then Gam-ut another Septenarie, they will be the ≈øame to tho≈øe above, onely eight Notes lower, and it is u≈øuall to di≈øtingui≈øh them thus:

Tho≈øe above Ela are called Notes in Alt, as F fa ut, and G ≈øol re ut, &c. in Alt: And tho≈øe below Gam-ut are called double Notes, as Double F fa ut, E la mi, &c. as being Eights, or Diapa≈øons to tho≈øe above Gam-ut, I have therefore in the Gam-ut of this Booke expre≈ø≈øed them in their right places: The Gam-ut is drawne upon foureteene Rules, and their Spaces, which comprehend all Notes or ≈øounds u≈øuall in Mu≈øicks either Vocall or In≈øtrumentall, though when any of the≈øe parts which it is divided into, come to be prickt out by it ≈øelfe, five lines is onely u≈øuall, as being ≈øufficient to containe the compa≈øs of Notes thereto belonging, if there be a Note that extends higher, it is u≈øuall to adde a line in that place with a pen. But for Le≈ø≈øons for the Organ, Virginalls, or Harp two ≈øtaves of ≈øix lines together are required, one for the left hand or lower Keyes, the other for the right or upper Keyes.

Therefore he that means to under≈øtand what hee ≈øings or plays, mu≈øt ≈øtudy to be perfect in the knowledge of the Gam-ut, and to have it perfectly in his memory without booke, both forwards and backe, and to di≈øtingui≈øh Cliffs and Notes, in Rule and in Space; for by knowing their places, their names are ea≈øily known.

This Scale or Gam-ut hath three Columns which ≈øhew the names of the Notes a≈øcending and de≈øcending in their ≈øeverall Keyes: the fir≈øt Columne is called B Duralis or B ≈øharp, as having no flat in B mi: the ≈øecond is B proper, or B Naturalis which hath a B flat in B mi onely: the third is called B fa or B Moralis, having two B flats, the one in B mi the other in E la mi, and in the≈øe three ob≈øerve that that what name the Note of any Cliffe hath, the ≈øame name properly hath his eight above or below him, be it either in Treble, Meane, or Ba≈ø≈øe.

There is an old Meeter, though not very common, yet it containes in it many pithy Rules of the Theorick part of Mu≈øick, which are to be ob≈øerved of tho≈øe who are yong beginners, and as it falls in our ≈øeverall Chapters I ≈øhall in≈øert it; it begins thus:

q.l: To attaine the skill of Mu≈øicks Art,
Learne Gam-ut up and down by heart,
Thereby to learn your Rules and Spaces,
Notes names are known knowing their places.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Cliffs or Cleaves.
div.p: IN the Gam-ut (as I ≈øaid before) is contained three Septenaries of Letters, which are, G.A.B.C.D.E.F. the≈øe 7 Letters are ≈øet at the beginning of each Rule and Space, and are called the ≈øeven Cleaves; of the≈øe ≈øeven, foure is onely u≈øuall: the fir≈øt is the F fa ut Cleave, which is only proper to the Ba≈ø≈øe, or lowe≈øt part, and is thus ≈øigned or marked ùÑ¢ The ≈øecond is the C ≈øol fa ut, which is proper to the middle, or inner parts, as Tenor, Counter-Tenor, or Meane, and he is thus ≈øigned or marked ùÑ° The third is the G ≈øol re ut Cleave, which is only proper to the Treble, or highe≈øt, and is ≈øigned or marked thus ùÑû

The≈øe three Cleaves are called the three ≈øigned Cleaves, becau≈øe they are alwayes ≈øet at the beginning of every line of a Song, or Le≈ø≈øon; for Cleave is derived from Clavis, which ≈øignifies a Key, for by this Key the places of all the Notes in the Song are known.

The fourth is the B Cleaves, which is proper to all parts, as being of two natures or properties, that is to ≈øay, Flat and Sharp, and doth onely ≈øerve for that purpo≈øe for the flatting and ≈øharping of Notes, and therefore he is called B fa, B mi: the B fa ≈øignifies Flat, the B mi Sharp, The
B fa or B flat, is known by this marke ‚ô≠ and the B mi, which is ≈øharp by this ‚ôØ.

But the≈øe Rules ob≈øerve of them both: Fir≈øt the B fa or B flat doth alter both the name and property of the Notes before which he is placed, and they are called Fa, making them halfe a tone or found, lower then they were before.

Secondly, the B mi or B ≈øharp alters the property of the Notes before which he is placed, but not their names; for he is u≈øually placed either before fa or ≈øol, and they retaine their names ≈øtill, but their ≈øound is rai≈øed halfe a tone or ≈øound higher.

div.head: CHAP. III. A briefe Rule for the proving the Notes in any Song or Le≈ø≈øon.
div.p: FIr≈øt ob≈øerve with what Cleave your Song or Le≈ø≈øon is ≈øigned with at the beginning, if it bee the G ≈øol re ut, then if the Note be above, you mu≈øt begin at G ≈øol re ut, and a≈ø≈øigne to every Space and Rule a Key according to your Gam-ut, a≈øcending till you come to the Rule or Space where he is ≈øet: If a Note below your Cleave, then you mu≈øt prove downwards to him, ≈øaying your Gam ut backward, a≈ø≈øigning to each Rule and Space a Key, till you come to his place.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Containing a plain and ea≈øie Rule for the naming your Notes in any Cleave.
div.p: HAving ob≈øerved the fore-going Rule of prooving your Notes to know their places, you may ea≈øily know the names al≈øo, if you follow this Rule: Fir≈øt ob≈øerve that Mi is the principall or ma≈øter Note, which leads you to know all the other; for having found out him, the other followes upon cour≈øe, and this Mi has his being in foure ≈øeverall places, but he is but in one of them at a time; his proper place is in B mi: But if a B fa, which as a B flat (as is mentioned in chap. 2.) be put in his place, then he is removed into Ela mi, which is his ≈øecond; but if a B flat bee placed there al≈øo, then he is in his third place, which is A la mi re; if a B flat come there al≈øo, then he is removed into his fourth place, which is D la ≈øol re, ≈øo that in which of the≈øe he is, the next Notes above him a≈øcending, are Fa ≈øol la, Fa ≈øol la twice, and then you meet with your Mi againe, for he is found but once in eight Notes: In like manner, the Notes next below him de≈øcending, are La ≈øol fa, La ≈øol fa, and then you have your Mi againe: I ≈øhall here in≈øert the old Meeter, with examples of the Notes, for the more ea≈øie under≈øtanding thereof in the ≈øeverall places.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of Tones, or Tunes of Notes.
div.p:
OB≈øerve that the 2 B. Cleaves before mentioned are u≈øed in Song for the altering of the tone or tune of Notes. the B flat changeth mi into fa, making him a ≈øemitone or half a note lower: and the B ≈øharp rai≈øeth the Note before which he is ≈øet halfe a Tone higher, but alters not their names, ≈øo that from Mi to fa, and likewi≈øe from la to fa is but halfe a tone, between any two other Notes is a whole tone, as
from fa to ≈øol, from ≈øol to la, and from la to Mi are whole Tones, and this may be ea≈øily di≈øtingui≈øhed if you trye it on the Frets of a Viol, you ≈øhal perceive plainly that there goes two frets to the ≈øtopping of a whole Note, and but one fret to a halfe Note; ≈øo that is ob≈øerved that Mi and fa doe ≈øerve for the flatting or ≈øharping the other ordinary Notes in the Scale, and they being rightly under≈øtood, the other Notes are ea≈øily applied to them; for if G ≈øol re ut have a ≈øharp ≈øet before him, it is A la mi re flat, and B mi flat is A re ≈øharp, and C. fa ut ≈øharp is D ≈øol. re flat, &c. as being of one and the ≈øame ≈øound. And it is ob≈øerved that a Diapa≈øon or perfect eight contains five whole tones and two halfe tones, that is in all the ≈øeven naturall ≈øounds, or Notes be≈øides the ground, what flats or ≈øharps ≈øoere there be. But for this I ≈øhall referre you to Doctor Campions excellent di≈øcour≈øe or Preface which is added at the end of this Booke.

div.head: CHAP. VI. The Notes, their names, proportions, and their Re≈øt or pau≈øes, with directions for keeping Time.

table.head: The Notes. Their Re≈øts or Pau≈øes.

div.p:
IT is to be ob≈øerved, that Notes have two names, one for Tune, as Sol la mi fa; the other for Time, or prolongation of ≈øounds, as fir≈øt the Large, 2. the Long, 3. the Briefe, 4. the Semibriefe, 5. the Minim, 6. the Crochet, 7. the Quaver, 8. the Semiquaver: and the≈øe eight Notes are thus di≈øtingui≈øhed, the Large being the fir≈øt and longe≈øt ≈øound, the re≈øt as they follow one another are halfe the proportion of the Note before him. The Semibriefe being the Ma≈øter Note; for in Songs or Le≈ø≈øons all Times are kept to his value, which is the hand up and downe: If it be a Long (which is a Note of Augmentation) 'tis foure Semibriefs, which is the hand foure times up and down: If Notes of Diminutions as Minims and Crochets, then ≈øuch a proportion of them as amount
to the value of one Semibrief is a Time, which is the hand up at one Minim and downe at the other.

The≈øe Notes have often times an augmentation or addition of a prick which followes them, which is for the continuing or prolonging of the ≈øound of that Note it follows, and the prick is halfe as much as the note which it follows: for example, if a prick be ≈øet after a Sembriefe, that prick addes a Minim more to him, and the Semibriefe which before but two Minims is now made to contain three Minims‚ñ™ the like is to the other Notes.

lg.l: The u≈øuall Moods may not here be mi≈øt,
In them much cunning doth con≈øi≈øt.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. The five Graecian Moods their Names. 1. The Dorick, 2. the Lydian, 3. the Aeolick, 4. the Phrygian, 5. the Ionick.
div.p:
1. THe Dorick Mood con≈øi≈øts of ≈øober ≈ølow timed Notes (or counterpoint) which in compo≈øition
of parts goes Note for Note, be they of two, three, or four parts, as is u≈øuall in Church Tunes to the u≈øuall P≈øalms, by Mr. Raven≈øcroft and others in foure parts, and other pious Canticles in Meeter; and this Dorick had his name from Doria, a civill part in Greece neare Athens.

2. The Lydian Mood was u≈øed to grave, full, ≈øolemn Mu≈øick, the De≈øcant or Compo≈øition being of ≈ølow time fitted to ≈øacred Hymnes, as Anthems, or ≈øpirituall Songs in pro≈øe, ≈øometimes in ver≈øes alone, and ≈øometimes in a full Chorus of foure or five parts. This Mood had its derivation from the famous River in Lydia called Pactolus, and the winding retrograde Meander, repre≈øenting thereby the admirarable varieties of ≈øounds in Mu≈øick in its pa≈ø≈øing by the chiefe Cities of Philadelphia and Sardis, being the Royall ≈øeat of the Rich Croe≈øus.

3. The Aeolick Mood was that which was of a more Ayery and ≈øoft plea≈øing ≈øounds, as your Madrigals, or Fa la's of five and ≈øix parts, which were compo≈øed for Viols and Voyces by many of our Excellent Engli≈øh Authours, as Mr. Morley, Wilkes, Wilbey, Ward, and others, and had his derivation from Aeolia (a Kingdome of Aeolus) whence hee is faigned to ≈øend his ru≈øhing windes, the which do re≈øemble this Mood, that is ≈øo commixt with fancy and Ayery ≈øounds.

4. The Phrygian Mood was a more warlike and couragious kinde of Mu≈øick, expre≈ø≈øing the Mu≈øick of Trumpets and other In≈øtruments u≈øed of old, exciting
to Arms and activity, as Almans, and the like. This Mood had it derivation from Phrygia (a region bordering upon Lydia and Caria) in which is Cios that martiall Mare Towne, and the mo≈øt high hill Ida famous for the Trojan war: and many Hi≈øtorians have written of its rare effects in warlike preparations. (Suidas in litera T.) writes of Timotheus a skilfull Mu≈øitian, that when Alexander the Great was much dejected in his minde, and loath to take up Armes, hee with his Phrygian Flute expre≈ø≈øed ≈øuch excellent ≈øounds and varieties of Mu≈øick that the Kings pa≈ø≈øions were immediatly ≈øtirred to war, and ran pre≈øently and took up Arms But the ≈øtory of Ericus Mu≈øitian, pa≈ø≈øes all, who had given forth that by his Mu≈øick he could drive men into what affections he li≈øted, being required by Bonus King of Denmarks to put his skill in practice, hee with his Harp or Polycord Lyra expre≈ø≈øed ≈øuch effectuall melody and harmony in the variety of changes in ≈øeverall Keyes, and in ≈øuch excellent Fugg's and ≈øprightly Ayres, that his Auditors began fir≈øt to be moved with ≈øome ≈øtrange pa≈ø≈øions; but ending his excellent voluntary with ≈øome choice Fancy upon this Phrygian Mood, the Kings pa≈ø≈øions were altred and excited to that height, that he fell upon his mo≈øt tru≈øty friends which were neare him, and ≈ølew ≈øome of them with his fi≈øt for lacke of another weapon, which our Mu≈øitian perceiving ended with the ≈øober Dorick: the King came to him≈øelfe and much lamented what he had done. This is recorded at
large by Kranzius lib. 5. Dania cap. 3. and by Saxo Grammaticus lib. 12. Hi≈øt. Daniae and others.

5. The Ionick Mood was for more light and effeminate Mu≈øick, as plea≈øant, amorous Songs, Coranto's, Sarabands and Jigs, u≈øed for hone≈øt mirth and delight in Fea≈øts and other merriments. This Mood had its derivation from the Ionian of Ionia, which lies between Aeolia and Caria a ≈øituation full of all plea≈øure, who≈øe plenty and idlene≈øs turned their hone≈øt mirth into la≈øciviou≈øne≈øs. By this Mood was the Pythagoreans Hunt≈øup or morning Mu≈øick, which wakened and rou≈øed their dull ≈øpirits to ≈øtudy and action. The abu≈øe of this Mood is ≈øoone reformed by the ≈øober Doricke, for what this excites above moderation, the other draws into a true Decorum.

div.p:
THere is nothing doth trouble, and di≈øgrace our Traditionall Mu≈øitian more, than the ambiguity of the termes of Mu≈øick, if hee cannot rightly di≈øtingui≈øh them, for they make him uncapable of any rationall di≈øcour≈øe in the Art he profe≈ø≈øeth: As if wee ≈øay a le≈ø≈øer Third con≈øi≈øts of a Tone, and a Semi-tone; here by a Tone is meant a perfect Sound, or (as they name it) a whole Note: But if we ask in what Tone is this or that Song made, then by Tone wee intend the Key
which guides and ends the whole Song. Likewi≈øe the word Note is ≈øometime u≈øed properly, as when in re≈øpect of the forme of it, wee name it a round or ≈øquare Note: in regard of the place we ≈øay, a Note in Rule, or a Note in Space; ≈øo for the Time, wee call a Briefe, or Sembriefe a long Note, a Crochet, or Quaver a ≈øhort Note. Sometime the word Note is otherwi≈øe to be under≈øtood, as when it is ≈øignum pro ≈øignato, the ≈øigne for the thing ≈øignified: ≈øo we ≈øay a Sharp, or flat Note, meaning by the word Note, the ≈øound it ≈øignifies; al≈øo we term a Note high, or low, in re≈øpect of the ≈øound. The word Note ≈øimply produced, hath yet another ≈øignification, as when we ≈øay this is a ≈øweet Note, or the Note I like, but not the words, we then meane by this word Note, the whole Tune, putting the part for the whole: But this word Note with addition, is yet far otherwi≈øe to be under≈øtood, as when we ≈øay a whole Note, or a halfe Note, we mean a perfect or imperfect Second, which are not Notes, but the ≈øeverall di≈øtances between two Notes, the one being double as much as the other; and although this kinde of calling them a whole and a halfe Note, came in fir≈øt by abu≈øion, yet cu≈øtom hath now made that ≈øpeech pa≈ø≈øable.
